page.title: 20BROCH AT BUCHLYVIE
page.content: {FAIRY KNOWE}Grid ref.586943, is a small green knoll 1 mile east of the village, first recorded as a{tumulus} in 1796 and since excavated in 1975. The site was discovered to be first of all a timber{round-house}of the Iron Age, about the 1st century A.D. in which the post holes were visible and parts of timber uprights remained. In the 2nd Century a{stone-built broch was erected on the same site, apparently with no break in occupation of the place, probably by Buchlyvie people. These later residents had a knowledge of weaving and working in metals, did mixed farming and were apparently in contact with the Roman forces either by trading or by looting.Some 500 small finds are in the{Smith Museum, Stirling.}Finds range from a Neolithic axe to Roman artefacts.
